dt: used to say that something would require too much time to read

dt.t: It was 70 years ago that poet W.H. Auden published "The Age of Anxiety," a six-part verse framing modern humankind's condition over the course of more than 100 pages, and now it seems we are too rattled to even sit down and read something that long (or as the Internet would say, {wi}tl;dr{/wi}—for "too long; didn't read").

dt: {bc}a briefly expressed main point or key message that summarizes a longer discussion or explanation

dt.t: The {wi}TL;DR{/wi} of all this, of course, is that you can't actually "disappear" from the Internet, even if you're a famous band. Which means that the best way to avoid unwanted digital traces may be simply to never make them.

A good Saturday [crossword puzzle] clue, in my opinion, will make your heart sink a little. It will take some work, there will be a point at which you hold your head in your hands, and then you will solve it …. So, {wi}tl;dr{/wi}: By the time you get to Saturday puzzles, relinquish the idea that you won't have to look anything up. There's no shame in learning something new.

dt: often used before another noun to describe something that provides summarizing information

shortdef: too long; didn't read — used to say that something would require too much time to read

a briefly expressed main point or key message that summarizes a longer discussion or explanation —often used interjectionally —often used before another noun to describe something that provides summarizing information
